And he starts with a shock. He calls us to become living sacrifices.

I. THE MOTIVATION: GOD'S MERCY (v. 1a)

Look at verse 1: "Therefore, I urge you, brothers and sisters, in view of God's mercy..."

Let's pause here for a moment on the word "mercy." Before we talk about our part, Paul points to the fuel. He doesn't say, "Do this or God will punish you." He says, "In view of God's mercy."

Everything we're about to discuss—dying to self, killing sin, pursuing holiness, being transformed, finding God's perfect will—flows from grace. We don't offer ourselves to earn God's favor. We offer ourselves because we're overwhelmed by His grace. Mercy comes first. Our surrender is the response.

If we try to die to self without grasping God's love, we'll end up bitter. Legalistic. Exhausted. This isn't a response of fear. It's a response of love. We love because He first loved us (1 John 4:19).

II. THE CALL: LIVING SACRIFICE (v. 1b)

Paul continues:

"...to offer your bodies as a living sacrifice, holy and pleasing to God—this is your true and proper worship."

In the Old Testament, a sacrifice was always a dead thing. You brought a bull, you killed it, and you left it on the altar. But Paul coins a new term: a living sacrifice.

Notice Paul says offer your bodies — not just your hearts or your souls. What we do with our hands, our eyes, our time — that's the offering. Christianity is not just spiritual. It's physical. It's incarnational. It's Monday through Saturday.

And notice he says this is our worship. The Greek word here is latreia — priestly service. Paul is saying our entire life becomes an act of worship, not just what we do on Sunday morning. Everything we say and do, we do all in the name of the Lord — it's all liturgy. It's all offering.

Something else we need to understand. In the Old Testament, whatever touched the altar belonged to God. It was no longer yours. When we offer ourselves, we're saying, "I am not my own. I belong to You."

And unlike a dead sacrifice that was offered once and done, a living sacrifice is continuous. It's offered every single morning. This isn't a one-time decision we made at an altar call ten years ago. It's a daily death. That's why Jesus said take up your cross daily.

Now here's the problem with a living sacrifice: it has a tendency to keep crawling off the altar.

We offer ourselves to God on Sunday, saying, "Lord, I am Yours. I belong to You." But by Monday morning, when the pressure hits, when the boss is rude, when the spouse is ungrateful, we crawl off the altar and take control back. "Actually Lord, I think I'll handle this one."

To be a living sacrifice is synonymous with "dying to self." But we must define this carefully.

It is NOT self-hatred, self-harm, or neglecting our physical needs.

It IS the deliberate surrender of our will, our rights, and our autonomy to the will of God.

Jesus put it this way in Matthew 16:24: "If anyone would come after me, let him deny himself and take up his cross daily and follow me."

To a first-century Jew, the cross wasn't a piece of gold jewelry. It was an instrument of execution. A one-way ticket. When a man picked up a cross, he was saying, "I am not coming back. My plans for tomorrow are cancelled. My rights are gone. I am under the authority of Rome."

To take up our cross means we wake up every morning and say: "I am dead to my own agenda today. I am alive to God's agenda."

How do we do this? Paul gives us the mechanics in Romans 6. He says we are "buried with Christ in baptism." When we went under the water, our "Old Self"—the slave to sin—had a funeral.

In Romans 6:11, Paul uses a banking term: "Reckon yourselves to be dead indeed to sin." To "reckon" (Greek: logizomai) means to calculate, to look at the ledger and accept the math as fact. We don't "feel" dead to sin; we "reckon" it as a legal fact. We stop trying to become dead to sin and start believing we are dead to sin.

We live from the victory, not for the victory.

III. THE STRUGGLE: WHY WILLPOWER FAILS

We all want to do this. We want to be patient, kind, and holy. But we fail. Why? Because we try to do it with willpower. And willpower is a terrible savior.

Let me share a personal illustration.

When I was a young boy, I was a terror. I had absolutely no self-control. I would torment my mother, refuse to do my chores, and run wild through the house. I knew the rules, but I simply didn't care. The impulse to rebel was stronger than my will to obey. My mother would plead with me. She would scold me. But my "flesh" was in charge.

But then, at 4:00 PM, the atmosphere in the house would change. I would hear the distinct sound of a car door slamming in the driveway. Then, the heavy turn of the front door handle. Then, the sound of my father's boots on the floor.

Instantly—without anyone saying a word—the chaos vanished. I didn't have to "try" to be good. I didn't have to grit my teeth and use willpower to sit still. The simple reality that my father was in the room silenced the rebellion. His presence brought an immediate order that my own willpower never could.

In the same way, our "flesh" is that unruly child. It acts up when we are spiritually disconnected. But when we enter the conscious presence of our Heavenly Father, the flesh is silenced. Temptations that screamed at us five minutes ago suddenly whisper—or disappear entirely. They cannot survive in the atmosphere of His holiness.

Here is the point: When we live our lives ignoring God, our flesh runs wild. We try to use willpower—the mother—to control it, but it doesn't work. We need the Father in the room.

Willpower strains and struggles. Presence commands and stills.

IV. THE METHOD: SPIRIT-LED MORTIFICATION (Romans 8:13)

So how do we bring the Father into the room? How do we practically put sin to death?

Paul says in Romans 8:13, "If by the Spirit you put to death the misdeeds of the body, you will live."

Notice: We cannot kill sin by the flesh—by willpower. We must do it by the Spirit.

When a sinful impulse arises—anger, lust, pride, anxiety—we need a plan. Follow this four-step protocol immediately.

Step 1: Agree with the Verdict

The moment the impulse hits, the Holy Spirit will check our conscience. Do not debate. Do not justify. Do not rename the sin.

We say, "I'm just venting." No. Call it murder. We say, "I'm just appreciating beauty." No. Call it adultery in the heart.

Call sin by its ugly biblical name immediately. Why? Because we cannot kill a friend. We only kill an enemy. Naming it strips its disguise.

Step 2: The Prayer of Helplessness

This is the shift from willpower to Spirit-power.

Do not grit your teeth, saying "I won't do this, I won't do this." That focuses on the sin, which actually feeds it. Instead, pivot your mind instantly to the Holy Spirit.

The prayer sounds like this: "Holy Spirit, I have zero power to stop this desire right now. My flesh loves this sin. I need You to kill it for me. I am relying entirely on Your power to break this chain."

This is dependency. Not willpower. Spirit-power.

Step 3: Wield the Sword of the Spirit

The Spirit wrote the Bible. When we quote Scripture, we are unleashing the Spirit's power directly at the temptation.

Quote a specific promise or warning at the temptation. If tempted by anxiety: "The Spirit God gave me does not make me timid, but gives me power, love and self-discipline." (2 Timothy 1:7). If tempted by fear: "When I am afraid, I will trust in You." (Psalm 56:3).

Why does this work? Because Jesus fought Satan in the wilderness not with logic, not with argument, but with three words: "It is written."

Step 4: Starve and Redirect

Death often comes by starvation. Physically remove the food source immediately. If the temptation is on a phone, throw the phone on the couch and walk away. If it's a conversation, excuse yourself and leave the room. Cut off the supply line.

But here's the key—we cannot just leave a void. We must immediately turn our affection to something superior. This is displacement. We don't just stop; we redirect.

THE BROKEN BRIDEGROOM

This leads us to the most vital concept of all. We cannot destroy a desire by simply removing it. We can only destroy it by replacing it.

What we are unable to do by willpower alone, we are able to do by setting our affection on another.

Let me illustrate.

Imagine a young man who falls deeply in love. The woman is stunning—the kind of beauty that captures a heart instantly. He loves her more than anything. He centers his entire world around her. He proposes, she accepts, and he spends every waking moment anticipating their life together.

But on the wedding day, as he stands at the altar, the doors do not open. Hours pass. She never comes. She has left him.

The man is devastated. He spirals into depression. His friends, trying to be helpful, come by his house. They pull open the curtains and say, "You have to get over this. Just use your willpower and move on!"

The man looks at them in despair and says, "Don't you understand? I am trying! But the harder I try not to think of her, the more she dominates my mind. Every time I tell myself 'Forget her,' I am remembering her again."

Finally, he decides the pain is too great. He cannot scrub her memory from his mind, so he decides to end his life. He walks to the apothecary to purchase poison, intending to go home, drink it, and end the suffering.

He walks into the shop, head down, defeated. But as he reaches for the poison, the shop door opens, and in walks a woman.

She is different. There is something radiant about her—not just her appearance, but her countenance. Kindness. Purity. In a single moment, the man is struck still. He has never seen anyone like her.

He strikes up a conversation, and that conversation leads to coffee, and coffee leads to courtship. She is everything the first woman was not: faithful, kind, and true. They marry and enter into a life of deep joy.

Six months later, the man is sitting on his porch, and he has a realization that shocks him: He hasn't thought about the woman who left him at the altar in months.

He didn't stop thinking about the first woman because he tried to. He didn't use willpower. He didn't shame himself into forgetting. He stopped thinking about the first woman simply because he was so consumed with love for the second one.

The Spiritual Application

This story illustrates the difference between religion and the gospel. Religion is willpower. The gospel is Spirit-power.

The first woman is sin—the world. It promises us happiness, but it leaves us empty at the altar. It betrays us, yet we obsess over it.

The friends represent the law. The law tells us what to do—"Stop sinning!"—but it gives us no power to actually do it.

The second woman is Jesus.

The only way to break the power of a lesser affection is the introduction of a superior affection. We do not die to self by staring at our sin and hating it. We die to self by staring at Jesus and loving Him.

As the old hymn says: "Turn your eyes upon Jesus, look full in His wonderful face, and the things of earth will grow strangely dim, in the light of His glory and grace."

So if the Father in the room silences the flesh, and worship is how we look at Jesus, how do we practically do this? How do we tune the dial to God's presence every day?

Here are four practices that bring us into the Father's presence.

First: Thanksgiving.

Psalm 100 says, "Enter his gates with thanksgiving." Don't start with complaints. Don't start with requests. Start by listing blessings. This shifts our mind from lack to abundance, from flesh to Spirit. Gratitude is the access code to God's presence.

Second: Confession.

We cannot enjoy the Father's presence if we are hiding secrets. Unconfessed sin creates static on the line. It doesn't remove our salvation, but it disrupts our communion. Confess sin immediately. Clear the channel.

Third: Silence.

We cannot hear God's footsteps if the TV is on. We cannot sense His presence if we are constantly distracted. We must withdraw to quiet places—even for five minutes—to remember that He is God and we are not.

Fourth: The Word.

The Bible is not just information about God. It is encounter with God. The Spirit who wrote it meets us in it. When we open Scripture expectantly, we are opening a door to His presence.

When we live in this state—constantly tuning back into the Father's presence through thanksgiving, confession, silence, and the Word—our flesh stays seated. The unruly child behaves. Not because we're trying harder, but because the Father is in the room.

V. THE RESULT: TRANSFORMATION (v. 2)

Now, look at the promise in Verse 2.

"Do not be conformed to the pattern of this world, but be transformed by the renewing of your mind. Then you will be able to test and approve what God's will is—his good, pleasing and perfect will."

Paul uses a very specific word here: "Be transformed by the renewing of your mind." The Greek word is metamorphoo. It is exactly where we get our word metamorphosis.

To understand what dying to self really looks like, we just have to look at the ugly, hairy caterpillar.

1. The Old Man (The Caterpillar)

Think about the life of a caterpillar. It is a creature of the earth. It crawls on its belly. It has one singular drive in life: consumption. A caterpillar is a voracious eating machine. It consumes hundreds of times its body weight. It takes, and takes, and takes. It destroys the very leaf it stands on to feed itself.

This is the picture of the old self—what Paul calls the flesh. The sinful nature is a consumer. It says, "I want. I need. Give me pleasure. Give me status. Give me comfort." It consumes relationships and people just to feed its own ego. It is earth-bound and ugly in its selfishness.

We know this nature. We have lived it.

2. The Coffin (The Cocoon)

But then, nature demands a death. The caterpillar stops eating. It spins a cocoon.

We often think of the cocoon as a warm, fuzzy sleeping bag. It is not. It is a tomb.

For the caterpillar to become a butterfly, it doesn't just sprout wings. If you were to cut open a cocoon halfway through the process, you wouldn't find a half-caterpillar, half-butterfly. You would find soup.

The caterpillar literally digests itself. It dissolves its muscles, its skin, its old structure—until it is nothing but genetic liquid.

This is Romans 12:1. This is the living sacrifice. This is dying to self.

We have to come to a place where we say, "Lord, dissolve me. Dissolve my pride. Dissolve my ambition. Dissolve my need to be right. I don't want to just be a better caterpillar. I want the old me to die completely."

This is the isolation from the world that Paul talks about. We stop conforming to the pattern of the other caterpillars who are just eating leaves, and we enter the secret place with God.

3. The New Creation (The Butterfly)

And then, the miracle happens. Out of that soup, a new structure is formed.

The butterfly emerges. And notice the total reversal of nature:

Locomotion: It no longer crawls in the dirt; it flies in the heavens. It is led by the Spirit, not the flesh.

Diet: It no longer chews up leaves; it drinks nectar. It tastes the goodness of God.

Purpose: This is the most amazing part. The caterpillar was a consumer—it killed plants. The butterfly is a pollinator—it gives life to plants.

When we die to self and let the Spirit renew our minds, we stop being consumers of people. We stop draining our spouse and our friends for validation. We become pollinators. We bring life, joy, and peace everywhere we land.

We cannot be pollinators if we are scared to enter the cocoon. We have to die to the caterpillar to live as the butterfly.

Here is the dangerous question—and let's be honest with ourselves:

If we cut open the cocoon of our lives right now, what would we see?

Would we see a dead caterpillar—a nature that has truly surrendered to God? Or would we see a caterpillar that is still fighting for control, still consuming, still refusing to die?

 

VI. NEW PERSPECTIVE AND KNOWLEDGE OF GOD’S WILL (v. 2)

This process of dying to self changes the way we see everything.

The Sun and the Marble

Many Christians live frustrated lives, constantly asking, "What's God's will for my life? Should I take this job? Should I marry this person?" And God seems frustratingly silent.

Do we know what the static is? Our will.

Imagine the sun. It is massive. It holds the planets in orbit. It burns with unimaginable fire.

Now imagine a marble. Small. Cold. Dead.

If we hold that marble up to our eye, it can completely block out the sun.

God's will is like the sun. It is massive. It is the big-picture plan for our lives. But our tiny desires are like that marble. "I want this job now." "I want this person to love me now." "I want this problem fixed now."

And we hold that marble so close to our eye that it eclipses the sun.

Dying to self means dropping the marble. It means saying, "Lord, my desires, my timeline, my plans—I release them." And when we drop the marble, the eclipse ends. The sun's light floods in. And we can finally see the path.

Then you will be able to test and approve what God's will is—his good, pleasing and perfect will.

God's will isn't hidden. We are just blocking it with our marble.

Let's pause here. What marble are we holding too close? What desire is blocking God's voice in our lives right now?

The Freedom of Death

So, what does this life of dying to self actually look like? It looks like freedom.

Dead to Reputation: When someone slanders us, we don't have to spend days defending ourselves. Why? Because a dead man doesn't care what people say about his corpse.

Dead to Outcomes: When we pour our heart into something and it fails, we can release it. Why? Because a dead man has already released his grip on everything.

Dead to Worry: When the future is uncertain, we can rest. Why? Because a sacrifice on the altar belongs to God. It's His problem now.

This is not a life of misery. This is a life of profound freedom.

We are finally free from the tyranny of self.

The altar isn't loss. It's encounter.

CONCLUSION

So we come back to the beginning. The system of the world and the system of God's kingdom are diametrically opposed.

The world says: Preserve yourself. Promote yourself. Actualize yourself.

The Kingdom says: Die.

But here is the glorious paradox: The one who loses his life will find it.

So we come to the altar. Not to try harder. Not to muster up more willpower. We come to die.

Here is my invitation to us.

This week, before your feet hit the floor each morning, pray this: "Lord, I am Yours. I lay myself on the altar today. Dissolve what needs to die. Fill me with Your Spirit. I am not my own."

And when the old nature rises—and it will—remember what we've learned. We don't white-knuckle our way to holiness. We agree with God's verdict on our sin. We pray the prayer of helplessness. We wield the Sword. We starve the flesh and redirect our affection toward Jesus.

Turn your eyes upon Jesus. Let the beauty of the Bridegroom displace the pull of the world. What we cannot do by willpower, we can do by setting our affection on another.

The caterpillar has to enter the cocoon. The marble has to drop from our hand. The sacrifice has to stay on the altar.

But the altar isn't loss. It's encounter.

We come to die. And in that death, we finally live.

SESSION EXTRAS

Key Scriptures for Study

Romans 12:1-2 — The primary text. Paul bridges theology (chapters 1-11) to application, calling us to become living sacrifices transformed by renewed minds.

Romans 6:11-14 — The "reckoning" passage. We count ourselves dead to sin and alive to God—not by feeling but by faith in what Christ accomplished.

Romans 8:13 — Spirit-led mortification. We put sin to death not by willpower but by the Spirit's power.

Matthew 16:24-25 — Jesus defines discipleship: deny yourself, take up your cross daily, follow Him. Lose your life to find it.

Galatians 2:20 — "I have been crucified with Christ. It is no longer I who live, but Christ who lives in me." The exchange at the heart of dying to self.

Psalm 100:4 — "Enter his gates with thanksgiving." The access code to God's presence that silences the flesh.

Discussion Questions

  1. Paul says we offer ourselves "in view of God's mercy." Why is mercy the fuel for dying to self? What happens when we try to die to self without grasping God's love first?

  2. The sermon describes living sacrifices as having "a tendency to crawl off the altar." Where do you most often crawl off? What triggers it?

  3. The Father's Footsteps illustration shows that presence commands what willpower cannot. Have you experienced a time when God's presence stilled a temptation that willpower couldn't defeat? What was that like?

  4. Review the 4-Step Protocol (Agree with the Verdict, Prayer of Helplessness, Wield the Sword, Starve and Redirect). Which step is hardest for you? Which do you tend to skip?

  5. The Bridegroom illustration teaches that we cannot destroy a desire by removing it—only by replacing it with a superior affection. What "first woman" (sin, distraction, false comfort) keeps pulling at your heart? How might turning your eyes to Jesus displace that pull?

  6. [DANGEROUS QUESTION] If we cut open the cocoon of your life right now, what would we find? A caterpillar that has truly surrendered? Or one still fighting for control, still consuming, still refusing to die?

  7. What "marble" are you holding so close to your eye that it's blocking the sun of God's will? What would it look like to drop it this week?

Practical Exercise: The Morning Altar

This week, practice the "Morning Altar" prayer before your feet hit the floor each day.

The Prayer:

"Lord, I am Yours. I lay myself on the altar today. Dissolve what needs to die. Fill me with Your Spirit. I am not my own."

Daily Tracker:

  • Did I pray before rising? What temptation arose? Which step did I use?

At the end of the week, review:

  • Did starting with surrender change how I faced the day?

  • When temptation came, did I default to willpower or Spirit-power?

  • What did I learn about the difference?

Weekly Challenge: Drop the Marble

Identify one "marble"—one desire, demand, or timeline—that you've been holding so close it's blocking your view of God's will.

Write it down: _______________________________

Each morning this week, physically hold a small object (a coin, a marble, a stone) in your hand during your prayer time. As you pray, deliberately open your hand and set it down.

Say: "Lord, I release this. Your will, not mine. Your timing, not mine."

Watch for what God reveals when the eclipse ends.

Prayer Focus

Lord Jesus,

We come to the altar today—not to try harder, not to muster up more willpower. We come to die.

Dissolve us. Dissolve our pride. Dissolve our ambition. Dissolve our need to be right, to be in control, to have our way. We don't want to be better caterpillars. We want the old self to die completely. Thank You that this isn't fueled by fear but by mercy. You loved us first. Our surrender is only a response to Your grace.

When the old nature rises—and it will—remind us of the protocol. Help us agree with Your verdict. Help us pray the prayer of helplessness. Help us wield the Sword. Help us starve the flesh and redirect our affection to You. Turn our eyes upon Jesus. Let the beauty of the Bridegroom displace the pull of the world. We drop our marbles. We enter the cocoon. We stay on the altar. Because the altar isn't loss. It's encounter.

In Jesus' name, Amen.

Memory Verse

Romans 12:1-2 (ESV)

"I appeal to you therefore, brothers, by the mercies of God, to present your bodies as a living sacrifice, holy and acceptable to God, which is your spiritual worship. Do not be conformed to this world, but be transformed by the renewal of your mind, that by testing you may discern what is the will of God, what is good and acceptable and perfect."

notes.title: Judged by the Light We Have
notes.content:
TEACHING OUTLINE

Text: Romans 2:12–16

Title: "Judged by the Light We Have"

Big Idea: God judges impartially by the light each person possesses—whether law or conscience—proving that everyone needs the rescue only Jesus provides.

I. THE QUESTION OF FAIRNESS (v. 12)

  • The "elephant in the room": Is God fair to those who never heard?

  • Paul’s answer: God judges based on what you have, not what you don’t have.

  • The Principle of Light:

    • Those with the Law (Jews/Church) judged by the Law.

    • Those without the Law (Gentiles/Unreached) judged without the Law.

  • Fairness isn't grading on a curve; it's grading based on the syllabus you received.

II. HEARERS VS. DOERS (v. 13)

  • Paul attacks religious presumption.

  • Proximity to truth does not equal piety.

  • Illustration: The medical student auditing the class.

    • He hears the lectures but cannot perform the surgery.

  • Key Truth: Judgment is evidence-based. God looks for fruit, not just attendance.

III. THE WITNESS WITHIN (vv. 14–15)

  • The Gentiles don’t have the Torah, but they have a witness.

  • Conscience: The Law written on the heart.

  • Evidence: Universal moral standards across history (courage, truth, justice).

  • Illustration: The internal recorder.

    • Conscience records our own standards.

    • On Judgment Day, God only has to play back our own condemnations of others.

  • Conscience is a great witness but a terrible savior. It can indict, but it cannot acquit.

IV. THE SECRET VERDICT (v. 16)

  • The standard shifts from outward actions to inward secrets.

  • "God judges the secrets of men by Christ Jesus."

  • This is the terror of the gospel: nothing is hidden.

  • This is the hope of the gospel: The Judge is also the Savior.

CONCLUSION

  • We have all failed the standard of the Law.

  • We have all failed the standard of Conscience.

  • We need a righteousness that comes from outside ourselves.

  • Call to Response: Come out of hiding. Let the light in.

DELIVERABLE 2: TEACHING MANUSCRIPT

INTRODUCTION

We are walking through the book of Romans together. We’re calling this series "The Missionary’s Handbook." We are following Paul—the greatest missionary in history—as he explains the gospel to the center of the world.

For the last few weeks, Paul has been dismantling our excuses.

In chapter one, he looked at the rebellious pagan world and said, "They are without excuse." In the beginning of chapter two, he looked at the moral religious person and said, "You are without excuse."

He is backing us into a corner. He is showing us that the ground is level at the foot of the cross.

But whenever you preach the gospel, there is a question that always comes up. It’s the elephant in the room. You may be thinking it right now.

"Okay, Paul. You say God judges everyone. But is that fair?"

Is God fair to judge people who never had the Bible? Is God fair to judge the person on a remote island who never heard the name of Jesus?

If God sends someone to hell who never had a chance to hear the gospel, isn't God unjust?

Paul knows we’re thinking this. And today, in Romans 2:12–16, he answers it. And his answer doesn’t just solve a theological riddle. It reads our mail.

Paul is going to show us that God’s judgment is perfectly fair, perfectly informed, and inescapable.

I. THE QUESTION OF FAIRNESS (v. 12)

Look at verse 12.

"For all who have sinned without the law will also perish without the law, and all who have sinned under the law will be judged by the law."

Here is Paul’s principle: God judges us by the light we have.

He divides the world into two groups.

First, there are those "under the law." In Paul’s day, that was the Jews. In our day, that’s us. The people with the Bibles. The people with the churches on every corner. The people who know the rules.

Paul says: You have the Law? Fine. You will be judged by the Law.

Then there is the second group. Those "without the law." The Gentiles. The unreached. The people who don’t have a Bible on their nightstand.

Paul says: They don't have the written Law? Fine. They won't be judged by a book they never read. They will "perish without the law."

Now, catch the nuance here. He doesn't say they are innocent. He says they have "sinned without the law."

Here is the fairness of God. God does not grade on a curve, but He does check the syllabus you were given. He holds you accountable for what you know, not for what you don't know.

But here is the scary part. That means those of us who know more are responsible for more.

We treat revelation like a trophy. We’re proud of our theology. We’re proud of our Bible knowledge. Paul says: Don't be proud. Be careful.

More light means more responsibility.

II. HEARERS VS. DOERS (v. 13)

Now Paul takes it a step further. He anticipates the religious person saying, "But I go to church! I hear the Word every Sunday! I agree with the sermon!"

Watch verse 13:

"For it is not the hearers of the law who are righteous before God, but the doers of the law who will be justified."

This cuts deep.

Paul is attacking the idea of "audit Christianity."

Imagine a medical student. He enrolls in medical school. He buys the sweatshirt. He goes to the lectures. He sits in the back and nods his head. "Yes, the heart has four chambers. Correct. I agree with that."

But he never goes to the lab. He never picks up a scalpel. He never learns to stitch a wound. He just audits the class.

Years later, you have a heart attack. You’re being wheeled into the O.R. And this guy walks in. He says, "Don't worry. I heard all the lectures."

Are you letting him operate on you? No.

Why? Because hearing is not doing.

Paul says there are people in the church who think they are right with God because they audit the faith. They agree with the doctrine. They like the music. They nod at the sermon.

But there is no fruit. There is no obedience. There is no change.

Paul says: On the Last Day, God isn't going to check your attendance record. He’s going to check your life.

Now, stay with me here. Paul is not saying we are saved by works. We’ll get to chapter 3 soon, where he says clearly that "by works of the law no human being will be justified."

Paul isn't telling us how to be saved here; he's telling us the standard of judgment. He’s saying, "If you want to be justified by the Law, you have to keep it perfectly."

Which, by the way, none of us do.

But the principle stands: Real faith produces real obedience. If you are a hearer but not a doer, you are deceiving yourself.

III. THE WITNESS WITHIN (vv. 14–15)

So, the religious person is guilty because they hear the Law but don't do it.

But what about the Gentile? What about the person who never heard the Law?

Look at verse 14:

"For when Gentiles, who do not have the law, by nature do what the law requires, they are a law to themselves, even though they do not have the law. They show that the work of the law is written on their hearts..."

This is fascinating. Paul says God wrote His book twice. Once on stone tablets for the Jews. And once on the human heart for everyone else.

We call this conscience.

Have you ever noticed that you can go to any culture in history, and certain things are always wrong? Cowardice is always looked down on. Betrayal is always condemned. Theft is always punished.

Why? Because we are made in the image of God. We have a moral compass built into our factory settings.

Paul says our conscience "bears witness." It's like a recorder.

Imagine if you had a tape recorder around your neck your whole life. And it didn't record what you did—it only recorded the moral judgments you made about other people.

Every time you said, "He shouldn't have lied to me." Click. Recorded.

Every time you said, "She shouldn't be so selfish." Click. Recorded.

Every time you said, "That's not fair." Click. Recorded.

On Judgment Day, God doesn't even have to open His book. He just has to press "play" on your recorder.

He will say, "I’m not going to judge you by the Bible you never read. I’m going to judge you by the standard you used on everyone else."

Did you live up to your own standard? Did you never lie? Did you never act selfishly?

Verse 15 says our conflicting thoughts "accuse or even excuse them."

Our conscience is a witness. And it’s a prosecuting attorney that never sleeps. It tells us, deeply and intuitively, that there is a right and a wrong, and that we have violated it.

Conscience is a great witness. But friends, it is a terrible savior. It can indict you, but it cannot acquit you. It can tell you you're sick, but it cannot heal you.

IV. THE SECRET VERDICT (v. 16)

So where does this leave us?

The religious person is guilty because they have the Law and don't keep it.

The irreligious person is guilty because they have a conscience and they violate it.

And then Paul drops the final hammer in verse 16:

"...on that day when, according to my gospel, God judges the secrets of men by Christ Jesus."

We tend to think judgment is about the big things. Murder. Adultery. Theft.

Paul says: No. God judges the secrets.

The motives. The hidden resentments. The lustful thoughts no one saw. The private words spoken in secret. The things you deleted from your browser history. The things you hope no one ever finds out.

God sees it all.

And notice who the Judge is. "By Christ Jesus."

This is the sober reality of the gospel. The Savior is also the Magistrate. The One who hung on the cross is the One who will sit on the throne.

This means we cannot hide. There are no secrets in heaven.

CONCLUSION

This is heavy. I know. Paul intends it to be heavy.

He wants us to feel the weight of this. He wants to strip away every excuse until we have nowhere to hide.

If you are relying on your religion—your "hearing" of the Word—it’s not enough.

If you are relying on your ignorance—"I didn't know"—your conscience testifies that you knew enough to be responsible.

We have all sinned against the light we have.

So what do we do?

If the verdict is guilty, is there any hope?

Look closely at verse 16 again. Paul calls this "my gospel." My good news.

How can judgment be good news?

Because the Judge is Jesus.

The same Jesus who will judge the secrets of men is the same Jesus who bore the shame of our secrets on the cross.

He took the penalty for the Law-breakers. He took the penalty for the Conscience-violators. He took the secrets, the shame, the hidden things, and He nailed them to the cross.

The only safe place to stand on Judgment Day is not in your innocence—you don't have any.

It is not in your ignorance—that won't work.

The only safe place to stand is in Christ.

So come out of hiding. Let the light in. Let your conscience be cleansed not by your excuses, but by His blood.

Let's pray.

DELIVERABLE 3: SESSION EXTRAS

KEY SCRIPTURES FOR STUDY

  • Romans 2:12–16 – The primary text: judgment by light, law, and conscience.

  • James 1:22–25 – Be doers of the word, and not hearers only. A mirror that exposes reality.

  • Psalm 19:1–4 – General revelation. The heavens declare the glory of God; knowledge is poured out day to day.

  • Hebrews 4:12–13 – The Word discerns the thoughts and intentions of the heart; no creature is hidden from His sight.

DISCUSSION QUESTIONS

  1. The Fairness Question: Before this sermon, how would you have answered the question, "Is it fair for God to judge people who never heard the gospel?" How does Paul’s argument in verse 12 change or sharpen your answer?

  2. Audit Christianity: Ideally, we want to be "doers." But where in your life do you tend to settle for just "hearing" or "auditing"? (e.g., listening to sermons but not changing habits, knowing theology but not loving people).

  3. The Conscience: The sermon used the illustration of a recorder playback. If your conscience played back the standards you judged others by this week, would you pass or fail your own test?

  4. Secrets: Verse 16 says God judges secrets. Does that thought bring you fear, relief, or a mix of both? Why?

  5. [DANGEROUS QUESTION] What is one "secret" area of your life—an attitude, a habit, or a resentment—that you have been hoping God would just ignore? Are you willing to bring it into the light today?

PRACTICAL EXERCISE: THE CONSCIENCE AUDIT

This week, take 10 minutes in silence to let your conscience speak. Ask the Holy Spirit to use your conscience to highlight one specific area where you are violating what you know is right.

  • Don't make excuses.

  • Don't defend yourself.

  • Just listen.

  • Write it down.

  • Confess it to God immediately and accept His forgiveness.

WEEKLY CHALLENGE

Identify your "Also the Greek." Paul says judgment is impartial, which means our mission must be impartial. Identify one person in your sphere of influence who is culturally, socially, or politically different from you. Pray for them by name every day this week.

PRAYER FOCUS

Father, thank You that You are a just Judge. You do not grade on a curve, but You judge with perfect equity. I confess that I have often been a hearer and not a doer. I confess that my own conscience condemns me. Thank You that Jesus Christ took the judgment I deserved. Cleanse my conscience by Your blood. Help me to live in the light, with no secrets and no hiding. In Jesus’ name, Amen.

MEMORY VERSE

"For it is not the hearers of the law who are righteous before God, but the doers of the law who will be justified." — Romans 2:13

notes.title: Religious Privilege and the Scandal of Hypocrisy
notes.content:
TEACHING OUTLINE

Text: Romans 2:17–29

Title: "Religious Privilege and the Scandal of Hypocrisy"

Big Idea: Religious privilege without personal integrity is a missional scandal that causes the world to blaspheme the God we claim to serve.

I. THE DANGER OF THE RESUME (vv. 17–20)

  • Paul pivots from the pagan to the religious person.

  • The Credentials:

  • Identity ("Jew")

  • Resource ("The Law")

  • Calling ("Guide to the blind")

  • The Trap: Relying on the possession of truth rather than the practice of truth.

  • Illustration: The Lighthouse.

  • A lighthouse with the best lenses but no light doesn't save ships; it watches them crash.

  • We polish our theology (the lens) but often fail to turn on the light (obedience).

II. THE MIRROR OF THE LAW (vv. 21–23)

  • Privilege brings responsibility.

  • The Interrogation:

  • You teach against stealing—do you steal?

  • You teach against adultery—do you commit it?

  • You abhor idols—do you rob temples?

  • Defining Hypocrisy:

  • It is not struggling with sin (that is normal Christianity).

  • It is masking sin. It is using the Law as a stage for performance rather than a mirror for repentance.

  • Illustration: The Health Inspector.

  • Grades restaurants on cleanliness but eats out of a dirty sink at home.

III. THE MISSIONAL SCANDAL (v. 24)

  • The consequence of hypocrisy is not just personal; it is missional.

  • The Verdict: "The name of God is blasphemed among the Gentiles because of you."

  • The Principle: Mission = Credibility + Clarity.

  • When we lack credibility, our clarity doesn't matter.

  • Illustration: Counterfeit Currency.

  • It looks right, but it lacks substance. When discovered, it destroys trust in the whole economy.

CONCLUSION

  • The bad news: We are all the hypocrite in the text.

  • The good news: The judgment drives us to Jesus.

  • We need a heart transplant, not a badge polish.

  • The Call: Repent of the mask. Let the world see a recovering sinner, not a fake saint.

DELIVERABLE 2: TEACHING MANUSCRIPT

INTRODUCTION

We are walking through the book of Romans as a missionary’s handbook. We are following Paul as he follows Christ.

For the last month, we have watched Paul dismantle every human excuse.

He looked at the pagan world—the world that has rejected God—and said, "You are without excuse."

He looked at the moralist—the person who thinks they are good enough—and said, "You are without excuse."

And today, he turns his eyes toward the hardest group of all.

He turns to the religious insider.

He turns to the people with the Bibles. The people with the pedigree. The people like us.

We live in a culture of credentials. We love our badges. We frame our diplomas. We list our ministries on our résumés. We take comfort in the fact that we belong to the right group, attend the right church, and hold the right theology.

But today, Paul takes a holy scalpel to our spiritual presumption.

He shows us that religious privilege without obedience is not just dangerous for our souls; it is a disaster for our mission.

He asks us a hard question: When people look at your life, do they bless the name of God, or do they mock it?

I. THE DANGER OF THE RESUME (vv. 17–20)

Look at verse 17. Paul starts listing the résumé.

"But if you call yourself a Jew and rely on the law and boast in God and know his will and approve what is excellent, because you are instructed from the law..."

Paul grants them the positives.

He says: You have the identity. You are part of the covenant people.

You have the resource. You have the Law—the very words of God.

You have the calling. Look at verse 19: you are confident that you are "a guide to the blind, a light to those who are in darkness."

This is all good.

To have the Bible is a privilege. To know the truth is a gift. To be able to teach others is a high calling.

But here is the danger.

We tend to turn our privileges into a shield. We think because we have the Book, we are safe. We think because we know the answers, we are righteous.

Paul says: Be careful. Privilege is not a shield; it is a stewardship.

The more light you have, the more you are responsible for.

Think of a lighthouse.

Imagine a lighthouse keeper who has the finest lenses money can buy. He has the strongest bulbs. He has the best tower. And every day, he polishes the brass. He cleans the glass. He studies the manual on how light refraction works.

But he never actually turns the light on.

Ships are crashing in the surf. Sailors are drowning in the dark.

And the keeper is up in the tower, boasting about how good his equipment is.

That is what it looks like to possess the Law but not practice it.

We polish our theology. We memorize our verses. We debate our doctrines.

But if the light of a transformed life isn't shining, our theology is useless.

Ask yourself this: Do you treat your Bible like a trophy, or like a tool?

Do you treat your knowledge like an ornament to admire, or an obligation to obey?

II. THE MIRROR OF THE LAW (vv. 21–23)

Now Paul moves from the résumé to the interrogation. And he gets uncomfortable.

He stops looking at what we have and starts looking at what we do.

Verse 21:

"You then who teach others, do you not teach yourself? While you preach against stealing, do you steal? You who say that one must not commit adultery, do you commit adultery? You who abhor idols, do you rob temples?"

He fires these questions like rounds from a pistol.

You tell people not to steal. But do you cut corners on your taxes? Do you steal time from your employer?

You tell people to be faithful. But is your heart full of lust? Are you faithful with your eyes?

He mentions "robbing temples." In that day, some Jews would publicly condemn idols but then buy and sell the gold stripped off pagan statues because it was profitable.

They hated the idol, but they loved the money.

Paul is exposing the gap. The gap between our mouth and our life.

We call this hypocrisy.

Now, we need to be careful here. We need to define what hypocrisy is—and what it isn’t.

Hypocrisy is not struggling with sin.

If you are a Christian, you will struggle with sin until the day you die. That doesn't make you a hypocrite; that makes you a human in need of grace.

Hypocrisy is different.

Hypocrisy is wearing righteousness as a mask while you cherish sin in your heart.

Hypocrisy is using the truth to judge others while you refuse to let it judge you.

It’s like a health inspector who goes around shutting down restaurants for having a speck of dust in the kitchen. He writes them up. He yells at the staff. He posts the failing grade on the door.

And then he goes home and eats dinner out of a dirty sink.

He knows the rules. He enforces the rules. But he doesn't live by the rules.

Paul asks us: "You who teach others, do you not teach yourself?"

Before you preach the sermon to your neighbor, have you preached it to your own soul?

Before you judge the world for its darkness, have you dealt with the darkness in your own heart?

III. THE MISSIONAL SCANDAL (v. 24)

Why does this matter?

Is it just about us being "good people"? No.

It matters because of the mission.

Look at the consequences in verse 24. This is the heaviest verse in the chapter.

"For, as it is written, 'The name of God is blasphemed among the Gentiles because of you.'"

Paul says when we say one thing and do another, the world doesn't just blame us. They blame God.

They don't just say, "That guy is a jerk." They say, "His God must be a joke."

Our hypocrisy becomes the world's best argument against the gospel.

Think about counterfeit money.

If you hand someone a counterfeit hundred-dollar bill, and they find out it’s fake, they don't just get mad at the paper. They lose trust in the currency.

It looks right on the outside. It has the right images. It has the right words.

But there is no value behind it.

When the world sees a Christian who is judgmental, unkind, greedy, or immoral, they see a counterfeit.

And they conclude that the whole system is bankrupt.

We are the commercial for the Kingdom of God.

If the commercial is annoying, false, or broken, nobody is going to buy the product.

This is the scandal.

We want to be missionaries. We want to reach our neighbors. We want to change our city.

But Paul says we are sabotaging our own mission.

We are blocking the door to the kingdom with our own inconsistency.

CONCLUSION

Paul has backed us into a corner.

We can't claim we didn't know—we have the Law.

We can't claim we are righteous—our conscience and our actions convict us.

We are standing before God, stripped of our badges, holding our broken masks.

So where is the hope?

If the religious person is just as lost as the pagan, who can be saved?

This is exactly where Paul wants us.

He wants to crush your confidence in your "resume" so that you will put your confidence in Jesus.

There is only one Person who ever lived who wasn't a hypocrite.

There is only one Person who kept the Law perfectly.

There is only one Person who preached truth and lived it without a single crack in the foundation.

Jesus Christ.

And the beauty of the gospel is this:

Jesus took the penalty for our hypocrisy. He took the shame of our secrets. He took the blasphemy we caused.

And He died for it.

God isn't looking for you to try harder to be perfect. He knows you can't.

He is looking for you to be honest.

The world doesn't need to see a "perfect" Christian. They know that doesn't exist.

They need to see a repentant Christian.

They need to see someone who says, "I fail. I struggle. I don't always get it right. But I have a Savior who does."

That is a witness the world cannot mock.

That is a light that actually shines.

So let’s drop the mask. Let’s come out of hiding.

Let’s stop polishing the badge and start washing our robes in the blood of the Lamb.

Let’s pray.

DELIVERABLE 3: SESSION EXTRAS

KEY SCRIPTURES FOR STUDY

  • Romans 2:17–24 – The primary text: The danger of reliance on the Law without obedience.

  • Matthew 23:25–28 – Jesus confronts the Pharisees about cleaning the outside of the cup while leaving the inside full of greed.

  • Psalm 51:6, 10–13 – David’s prayer after his own hypocrisy was exposed. "You delight in truth in the inward being."

  • Titus 1:16 – "They profess to know God, but they deny him by their works."

DISCUSSION QUESTIONS

  1. The Resume: Paul lists the privileges of the Jews (vv. 17–20). What are the modern equivalents for us? What "badges" do we tend to rely on for our spiritual confidence?

  2. The Distinction: The sermon distinguished between "struggling with sin" and "hypocrisy." How would you explain that difference to a new believer? Why is this distinction vital for our mental health?

  3. The Mirror: Which of Paul’s questions in verses 21–23 hit closest to home for you? Where is the gap between your theology and your reality?

  4. The Scandal: Have you ever seen someone turn away from God because of the behavior of a Christian? How does verse 24 impact the way you view your daily interactions?

  5. [DANGEROUS QUESTION] If your non-Christian co-workers or neighbors could see a transcript of your private thoughts and hidden actions from this past week, would they be shocked to find out you are a Christian?

PRACTICAL EXERCISE: THE INTEGRITY AUDIT

This week, choose one "domain" of your life to audit for integrity:

  1. Work: Do you work as hard when the boss isn't looking?

  2. Home: Are you as kind to your spouse/kids as you are to guests?

  3. Digital: do you type things you would never say face-to-face?
    Identify one gap. Confess it to a trusted friend. Ask them to check in on you in that specific area next week.

WEEKLY CHALLENGE

Repair your credibility. Is there someone you have wronged—a spouse, a child, a colleague—where you acted in a way that didn't match your faith? Go to them this week. Don't make excuses. Just say, "I was wrong. I didn't act like a follower of Jesus should. Will you forgive me?"

PRAYER FOCUS

Father, I confess that I often hide behind my religious resume. I know the right words, but my heart is often far from You. Search me, O God. Expose the areas where I am wearing a mask. Thank You that Jesus died for hypocrites like me. Give me the courage to be honest about my struggles, so that Your strength can be made perfect in my weakness. Let my life bring honor, not blasphemy, to Your name. Amen.

MEMORY VERSE

"You who boast in the law dishonor God by breaking the law. For, as it is written, 'The name of God is blasphemed among the Gentiles because of you.'" — Romans 2:23–24

notes.title: Stott: Warnings, Messages, and Doxology
notes.content:
His warnings, messages and doxology

16:17–27

Some find Paul's transition from greeting to warnings very abrupt, and the tone of his admonition so harsh as to be inconsistent with the rest of his letter, and especially with his gentle handling of the weak. They therefore wonder if verses 17–20 were written by another hand than Paul's. But it is readily understandable that his mind should move from the Roman church's unity in diversity (to be expressed in the kiss of peace) to the menace of those who were threatening divisions. Moreover, Paul's conciliatory attitude to the weak reflected his respect for sensitive consciences; his severity to the false teachers was aroused by their deliberate mischief in disrupting the fellowship and contradicting apostolic teaching. Having said this, we still do not know who they were. Paul's language is too indefinite to permit certainty. All we can say is that, since they served themselves instead of Christ (18), they had antinomian tendencies.

1. Paul's warnings (17–20)

Paul begins his exhortation with the same words which he has used to introduce an earlier one: I urge you, brothers (17, cf. 12:1). He issues a threefold appeal—to vigilance, to separation and to discernment.

First, Paul pleads for vigilance: watch out for (jb 'be on your guard against') those who cause divisions and put obstacles in your way, hindering your progress, that are (both of them) contrary to the teaching you have learned (17). Of course some divisions are inevitable, like those caused by loyalty to Christ, and so are some obstacles (skandala), especially the stumbling-block of the cross (9:32f.). Paul urges the Romans to look out for those who cause them because they contradict the teaching of the apostles. He takes   p 400  it for granted, even thus early in the church's history, that there is a doctrinal and ethical norm which the Romans must follow, not contradict; it is preserved for us in the New Testament.

Secondly, Paul calls for separation from those who deliberately depart from the apostolic faith. Keep away from them, he writes. There is no question of approaching them with a holy kiss, but rather of standing aloof, and even turning away. Why is this? What is the essence of their deviation? Paul tells us. For such people are not serving our Lord Christ, but their own appetites (18a), literally 'their own belly' (av). This is very unlikely to be an allusion to the controversy over the Jewish food laws. It is rather a graphic metaphor of self-indulgence (as in Phil. 3:19, 'their god is their stomach'). The expression is used 'in the sense of serving oneself, of being the willing slave of one's egotism'. These false teachers have no love for Christ, and no wish to be his willing slaves. Instead, they are 'utterly self-centred' (jbp), and also have a baneful effect on the gullible. By smooth talk and flattery they deceive the minds of naïve people (18b). Better, 'they seduce the minds of simple people with smooth and specious words' (reb).

Thirdly, Paul urges the Romans to grow in discernment. On the whole he is very pleased with them. Everyone has heard about your obedience, he says, so I am full of joy over you (19a). Nevertheless, there are two kinds of obedience, blind and discerning, and he longs for them to develop the latter: but I want you to be wise about what is good, and innocent about what is evil (19b). To be wise in regard to good is to recognize it, love it and follow it. With regard to evil, however, he wants them to be unsophisticated, even guileless, so completely should they shy away from any experience of it. J. B. Phillips captures the contrast well: 'I want to see you experts in good, and not even beginners in evil.'

Here then are three valuable tests to apply to different systems of doctrine and ethics—biblical, Christological and moral tests. We could put them in the form of questions about any kind of teaching we come across. Does it agree with Scripture? Does it glorify the Lord Christ? Does it promote goodness?

In verse 20 Paul adds an assurance to his warning. He has written about good and evil; he wants the Roman Christians to know that there is no doubt about the ultimate outcome, the triumph of good over evil. He detects the strategy of Satan behind the activity of the false teachers, and he is confident that the devil is going to be overthrown. The God of peace will soon crush Satan under your feet   p 401  (20a). That is, God 'will throw him under your feet, that you may trample upon him'. He has already been decisively defeated; but he has not yet conceded his defeat.

It may seem strange that in the context Paul refers to 'the God of peace' (as in 15:33), since enjoying peace and crushing Satan do not sound altogether compatible with each other. But God's peace allows no appeasement of the devil. It is only through the destruction of evil that true peace can be attained.

Probably there is an allusion to Genesis 3:15, where God promised that the seed of the woman (namely the Christ) would crush the serpent's head. But there is surely a further reference to man, male and female, whom God created and to whom he gave dominion. As the psalmist put it, God has 'put everything under his feet'. So far this has been fulfilled only in Christ, since God has put 'all things under his feet'.7 Yet still his exaltation is incomplete, for, while he reigns, he also waits for his enemies to be made his footstool. That this will happen 'soon' is not necessarily a time reference, but rather a statement that God has planned nothing to occupy the space between the ascension and the parousia. The parousia is the very next event on his calendar. Meanwhile, the Romans should expect regular interim victories over Satan, partial crushings of him under their feet.

Such victories would be impossible, however, apart from grace. So Paul adds: The grace of our Lord Jesus be with you (20b).

2. Paul's messages (21–24)

Having sent his own personal greetings to twenty-six individuals in Rome (3–16), Paul now passes on messages from eight named people, who are with him in Corinth. He begins with one extremely well-known name, followed by three apparently unknown ones. Timothy, my fellow-worker, sends his greetings to you, as do Lucius, Jason and Sosipater, my relatives (21). If anybody deserved to be called Paul's 'fellow-worker', that person was Timothy. For the last eight years Timothy had been Paul's constant travelling companion and had undertaken several special missions at Paul's request. The apostle evidently had a warm affection for his young assistant. Having led him to Christ, he regarded him as his son in the faith. He was now in Corinth, about to set sail for Jerusalem with the offering from the Greek churches.10

From his fellow worker Paul turns to three of his fellow countrymen, as his 'relatives' should probably be understood. We   p 402  cannot for certain identify any of them, although many guesses have been made, some more plausible than others. For example, although there is nothing to link Lucius with the 'Lucius of Cyrene' who was in Antioch with Paul ten years previously, it is tempting to identify him as Luke the evangelist, since we know from one of his tell-tale 'we' passages that he was in Corinth at the time.12 The only difficulty is that Luke was a Gentile. But then 'my fellow-countrymen' could refer only to Jason and Sosipater. This Jason could quite easily be the Jason who had been Paul's landlord in Thessalonica, and Sosipater could be the Berean church's delegate to Jerusalem, whose name was abbreviated to Sopater,14 for he too was in Corinth at the time.

At this point Paul allows his scribe, to whom he has been dictating this letter, to write his own greeting. I, Tertius, who wrote down this letter, greet you in the Lord (22).

Next comes a message from Paul's host in Corinth. Gaius, whose hospitality I and the whole church here enjoy, sends you his greetings (23a). Several men called Gaius appear in the New Testament, for it was a common name. It would be natural, however, to identify this one with the Corinthian whom Paul had baptized. Some scholars have further suggested that his full Roman name was Gaius Titius Justus, in which case he had a large house next to the synagogue, into which he had welcomed Paul after the Jews had rejected his gospel.16 It is then understandable that Paul would again be his house guest, and that the church would also meet in his home.

Two further people complete the series of messages from Corinth. Erastus, who is the city's director of public works (rsv 'the city treasurer'), and our brother Quartus send you their greetings (23b). Of Quartus nothing is known, although F. F. Bruce asks if it would be 'excessively far-fetched' to think of him as Tertius' younger brother, since tertius means 'third' and quartus 'fourth'. In response, C. E. B. Cranfield dubs Bruce's guess 'an exercise of free fancy'. Erastus, on the other hand, however we should translate 'the oikonomos of the city', seems to have been a responsible local government official. Perhaps he was the aedile, the magistrate in charge of public works, whose name is still clearly legible in a first-century Latin inscription on a marble pavement close to the ruins of old Corinth. It is difficult to see, however, how he could at the same time have been one of Paul's itinerant helpers who on one occasion was sent 'to Macedonia', although on another he 'stayed in Corinth'.19

  p 403  3. Paul's doxology (25–27)

Paul's doxology is an eloquent and appropriate conclusion to his letter, for he takes up its central themes, summarizes them and relates them to one another. Although the grammar of the doxology is not easy to unravel, it contains profound truths about God and the gospel. It consists of four parts which focus respectively on the power of God, the gospel of Christ, the evangelization of the nations and the praise of God's wisdom.

First, Paul writes of the power of God. Now to him who is able (dynamenō, has the dynamis) to establish you.… Although this accurately translates the Greek, it is an awkward introduction, and jb does better to begin with a noun: 'Glory be to him who is able …!' It can hardly be an accident that Romans begins and ends with a reference to the power of God through the gospel. If the gospel is God's power to save (1:16), it is also God's power to establish. Stērizō (to establish) is almost a technical term for nurturing new converts and strengthening young churches. Luke uses it in the Acts (or rather the cognate verb epistērizō) of Paul and his fellow missionaries, who deliberately revisited the churches they had planted, in order to 'establish' them. And Paul himself uses the verb in his letters in relation to making Christians firm, strong and stable, whether in their faith (against error), in their holiness (against temptation) or in their courage (against persecution).22 So the vision conjured up by the doxology's opening words is of God's ability to establish the multi-ethnic church in Rome, of which Paul has been dreaming, and to strengthen its members in truth, holiness and unity.

Secondly, Paul writes of the gospel of Christ. For God is able to establish you, he says, by (literally 'according to') my gospel and the proclamation of Jesus Christ, according to the revelation of the   p 404  mystery hidden for long ages past (25), but now revealed … (26a). The Greek sentence has three coordinate clauses, namely 'according to my gospel', 'and [according to] the proclamation of Jesus Christ', and 'according to the revelation of the mystery'. But the first two are almost identical, since Paul's gospel was essentially a proclamation (kērygma) of Christ. What Paul is affirming is that God's power to establish the church is part of his gospel, of his proclamation. This reminds us of the first three verses of his letter, in which he described himself as 'set apart for the gospel of God … regarding his Son'. Now he refers to 'the gospel of God' as 'my gospel' (cf. 2:16), because it had been revealed and entrusted to him by God, and the gospel 'regarding his Son' he calls 'the proclamation of Jesus Christ'.

The third coordinate clause ('according to the revelation of the mystery') emphasizes the fact that his gospel is revealed truth. It is a 'mystery', that is to say, a truth or cluster of truths hidden for long ages past, but now revealed. What is included in the 'mystery' Paul does not here explain. But he does elsewhere. God's secret, hitherto concealed but now revealed, is essentially Jesus Christ himself in his fulness, and in particular Christ for and in the Gentiles,24 so that Gentiles now have an equal share with Israel in God's promise. The mystery also includes good news for Jews as well as Gentiles, namely that one day 'all Israel will be saved' (11:25f.). And it looks forward to the future glory, when God will bring all things together under one head, Christ.27 Thus the mystery begins, continues and ends with Christ.

Thirdly, Paul writes of the evangelization of the nations. It is important to grasp that Paul is stating three truths about the mystery, which are summed up by the verbs hidden, revealed and made known. It is not just that the mystery was long concealed, but has now been revealed, namely through the life, death, resurrection and exaltation of Jesus. The third fact is that this good news must be, and is already being, made known throughout the world: made known through the prophetic writings by the command of the eternal God, so that all nations might believe and obey him (26b).

Consider now four significant features of the universal 'making known' of the gospel mystery, which are strongly reminiscent of the letter's opening paragraph (1:1–5). Both passages (the introduction and the doxology) refer to the Scriptures, the commission of God to evangelize, the obedience of faith, and all the nations.

First, the mystery is being made known through the prophetic writings, which must mean Old Testament Scripture. But how can   p 405  God be making known his mystery through the Old Testament now, when it has been in existence for centuries? The answer seems to be that, following the saving events of Christ, God has given his people a new Christological understanding of the Old Testament as bearing witness to Christ (cf. 1:2; 3:21). In consequence, it is through the apostolic declaration that 'the Christ is Jesus' that the gospel is spreading.

Second, the clause by the command of the eternal God must refer to the universal commission to preach the gospel, for behind the risen Christ who gave it there stood the eternal God, whose everlasting purpose it is to save and unite Jews and Gentiles in Christ.

Third, the clause 'unto obedience of faith' (translated might believe and obey him) comes next in the Greek text. It is identical with 1:5. The proper response to the gospel is faith, as Paul has stressed throughout his letter, but it is a faith which itself is obedient and which issues in a life of obedience.

Fourth, the contemporary 'making known' of God's mystery is for all nations, so that they will believe and obey. No limit is placed on the beneficiaries of the gospel; it is intended for everybody.

So this fourfold scheme of the making known of the gospel through Scripture, by God's command, unto obedience of faith, for all the nations, exactly corresponds to the letter's opening, which refers to the gospel as being, among other things, according to the Scriptures, through the grace and apostleship given to Paul and others, unto obedience of faith, and for all the nations.

Finally, Paul concludes in praise of God's wisdom: to the only wise God be glory for ever through Jesus Christ! Amen (27). God's wisdom is seen in Christ himself, 'in whom are hidden all the treasures of wisdom and knowledge', above all in his cross which, though foolish to human beings, is the wisdom of God,30 in God's decision to save the world not through its own wisdom but through the folly of the gospel, in the extraordinary phenomenon of the emerging multiracial, multicultural church;32 and in his purpose ultimately to unite everything under Christ. No wonder Paul has already broken out in praise of God's wisdom: 'Oh, the depth of the riches of the wisdom and knowledge of God!' (11:33). No wonder he does it again at the end of his letter. Indeed, God's redeemed people will spend eternity ascribing to him 'praise and glory and wisdom and thanks and honour and power and strength'. That is, they will worship him for his power and wisdom displayed in salvation.

It is fair then to say that the major themes of Paul's letter are   p 406  encapsulated in the doxology: the power of God to save and to establish; the gospel and the mystery, once hidden and now revealed, which are Christ crucified and risen; the Christ-centred witness of Old Testament Scripture; the commission of God to make the good news universally known; the summons to all the nations to respond with the obedience of faith and the saving wisdom of God, to whom all glory is due for ever.

 John R. W. Stott, The Message of Romans: God's Good News for the World, The Bible Speaks Today (Leicester, England; Downers Grove, IL: InterVarsity Press, 2001), 399–406.
